content: The report summarizes the USDA's efforts to establish a national animal traceability system for rapid disease outbreak response. Despite economic benefits, federal proposals face controversy within the U.S. cattle industry. The background of animal ID and traceability, along with unresolved issues and differing views on a national system, are discussed. Appendices detail the development of the U.S. National Animal Identification System and its successor program. On February 5, 2010, Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack announced the revision of the U.S. National Animal Identification System (NAIS) to a new approach called Animal Disease Traceability. This new system allows states and tribal nations to choose their own level of animal identification and traceability for livestock populations. Under the new Animal Disease Traceability framework, USDA requires all animals moving in interstate commerce to have traceable ID back to their originating state. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to regulate interstate movement of farm-raised livestock. USDA has collaborated with state and tribal officials to establish a Traceability Regulation Working Group. The USDA established a Traceability Regulation Working Group with state, tribal nation, and APHIS officials to develop a proposed rule for animal disease traceability. Feedback was gathered through forums and public meetings, leading to the release of two publications outlining USDA's recommendations for the proposed rule in August 2010. The USDA's traceability framework is still evolving, with states and tribal nations being responsible for managing traceability programs. States have the option to implement mandatory animal ID systems or rely on existing systems to combat diseases like brucellosis and tuberculosis. The within-state programs are intended to be implemented by the states. The federal rules for animal disease traceability will only apply to livestock moving in interstate commerce. Livestock will need official identification and an Interstate Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (ICVI) when moving interstate. Exemptions will be defined in the rules, such as cattle going directly to slaughter. Acceptable official identification types will be specified in federal regulations. State and tribal nation traceability capacity will be evaluated based on defined performance standards. The Traceability Regulation Working Group, along with state and tribal animal health officials, will define performance standards for animal disease traceability. Each state and tribal nation will have detailed traceability cooperative agreements with APHIS, with federal funding provided through annual agreements. No funding is designated for animal traceability in the agriculture appropriations bill for FY2011, but funding could be considered later. The Senate Committee on Appropriations report indicates that funding for animal disease traceability could be considered after needs are identified under USDA's new initiative. The program will be implemented through federal regulations and the federal rulemaking process, with a proposed rule expected to be published in April 2011.
